problem.text:
Let [mathjaxinline]\{ w_1; w_2; w_3\}[/mathjaxinline] be an
orthogonal] basis of a subspace [mathjaxinline]W[/mathjaxinline] of [mathjaxinline]\mathbb R^4[/mathjaxinline]. Suppose that [mathjaxinline]w_1 = \left[ \begin{array}{c} 1 \\ -1 \\ -1 \\ 1 \end{array} \right][/mathjaxinline].
Suppose further that [mathjaxinline]v = \left[ \begin{array}{c} 3 \\ 4 \\ 7 \\ 1 \end{array} \right][/mathjaxinline] is also an element of [mathjaxinline]W[/mathjaxinline].
Since it is an element of [mathjaxinline]W[/mathjaxinline], we can write [mathjaxinline]v[/mathjaxinline] as a linear combination [mathjaxinline]v = a_1 w_1 + a_2 w_2 + a_3w_3[/mathjaxinline]. What is [mathjaxinline]a_1[/mathjaxinline]?
Answer:
We know that [mathjaxinline]v[/mathjaxinline] is its own projection onto [mathjaxinline]W[/mathjaxinline]. Hence
[mathjax]a_1 w_1 + a_2 w_2 + a_3w_3 = v = \mathrm{Proj}_ W(v) = \frac{\langle v, w_1 \rangle }{\langle w_1, w_1 \rangle } w_1 + \frac{\langle v, w_2 \rangle }{\langle w_2, w_2 \rangle } w_2 + \frac{\langle v, w_3 \rangle }{\langle w_3, w_3 \rangle } w_3.[/mathjax]
Hence [mathjaxinline]a_1 = \frac{\langle v, w_1 \rangle }{\langle w_1, w_1 \rangle } = -\frac{7}{4}.[/mathjaxinline]
